snippet: China erupted in something close to a national celebration for the writer Mo Yan, just two years after the government condemned a Nobel Peace Prize for the dissident Liu Xiaobo.
abstract: China erupts in something close to national celebration for writer Mo Yan, who won the Nobel Prize for literature, just two years after the government condemned Nobel Peace Prize for dissident Liu Xiaobo; award will probably act as huge boost to China's national psyche, which has suffered from sense that its cultural accomplishments are overshadowed by its economic prowess.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS and SARAH LYALL
byline.contributor: Andrew Jacobs reported from Beijing, and Sarah Lyall from London. Ian Johnson contributed reporting from Beijing, and Alan Cowell from Paris. Shi Da and Jonathan Ansfield contributed research.

lead_paragraph: China erupted in something close to a national celebration for the writer Mo Yan, just two years after the government condemned a Nobel Peace Prize for the dissident Liu Xiaobo.

headline.seo: Chinese Writer Mo Yan Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
headline.main: After Fury Over 2010 Peace Prize, China Embraces Nobel Selection
headline.print_headline: After Past Fury for Peace Prize, China Embraces Nobel Choice
